In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Cambodia has requested technical assistance (TA) from the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  pursue  a  decentralization  program  to  reform  the  roles  and 
responsibilities for subnational administration and to institute appropriate fiscal arrangements at 
subnational levels. ADB’s country strategy and program, 2005–2009,1 and country operations 
business  plan,  2008–2010,2 highlight  the  importance  of  ADB  involvement  in  strengthening 
public administration reforms in Cambodia, particularly in areas of public financial management 
and decentralization. A fact-finding mission for this policy and advisory TA was fielded from 8–
17  July  2009,  and  agreement  was  reached  with  the  Government  on  its  purpose,  scope, 
implementation  arrangements,  and  financing.  The  design  and  monitoring  framework  is  in 
Appendix 1.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Decentralization and deconcentration are key governance reforms for local democratic 
development and service delivery improvement. The election of commune councils in 2002 was 
the first step toward these goals. Then, in 2005, a strategic framework established the basic 
principles and scope for a comprehensive decentralization program. This program now forms 
part of the good governance strategy of the National Strategic Development Plan, 2006–2010,4 
which  has  been  extended  to  2013.  The  plan  defines  the  main  policies  and  principles  for 
administrative reform at the provincial/municipal and khan (district) levels and for strengthening 
ongoing sangkat (commune)-level reforms. The plan’s overall objective is to enable subnational 
administrations to participate effectively in the country’s overall poverty reduction and economic 
development. The Government's Rectangular Strategy5 also recognizes good governance as a 
pillar for sustainable socioeconomic development.   
 
3.  In  May  2008,  the  Organic  Law  was  passed,  requiring  the  establishment  of  new 
subnational structures and systems and reassigning functions and resources between national 
and subnational levels. It created a framework for (i) instituting three levels of subnational 
administration  (provinces,  municipalities  or  khans,  and  sangkats)  with  elected  councils;  (ii) 
appointing boards of governors to act as both chief executives of the provinces/khans and 
supervisors of provincial departments of national ministries; (iii) enabling councils to appoint 
their  own  staff  members;  (iv)  enabling  councils  to  be  responsible  for  their  own  financial 
administration, with budgets approved by the Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF) and 
National Assembly; and (v) establishing the National Committee for Democratic Development at 
the Subnational Level (NCDD) to review ministries’ functions and to determine which functions 
will be assigned to subnational levels.  
 
4.  NCDD  is  an  interministerial  entity  comprising  four  subcommittees  focused  on  (i) 
functions and resources, led by the Ministry of Interior (MOI); (ii) financial and fiscal affairs, led 
by MEF; (iii) subnational administrative personnel, led by the State Secretariat for Civil Service; 
and (iv) subnational policy, legislation, and guidelines of development plans and investment 
programs, led by the Ministry of Planning. Decentralization and deconcentration committees

group to coordinate the reform agenda across the Government, to finalize a draft subnational 
finance law, and to coordinate public financial management and decentralization reforms. A 10-
year National Program for Subnational Democratic Development (National Program) is also 
being prepared by NCDD and will be completed by the end of 2009. 
 
5.  A strong link between national priorities and plans with decentralized service delivery will 
enhance  the  effectiveness  and  efficiency  of  the  Government's  resource  utilization  and 
strengthen accountability and transparency. Since 2008, ADB has been providing assistance for 
this purpose through the Commune Council Development Project, phase 2.6 This project has 
provided  commune  councils  with  necessary  facilities,  capacity  development  for  commune 
councilors and officials, and a civil registration system. Simultaneously, the Public Financial 
Management  Program  for  Rural  Development7 is  strengthening  financial  management  and 
internal audit processes in ministries associated with rural development as well as building the 
capacity of the National Audit Authority.  
 
6.  ADB's engagement with decentralization and deconcentration is critical to the overall 
delivery of the country strategy situated in a range of sectors and thematic areas involving, 
dominantly, the lower tiers of administration. ADB staff members have undertaken intensive 
consultation and dialog with a range of stakeholders (including MEF, MOI, Supreme National 
Economic  Council,  provincial  and  district  administrations,  line  ministries,  and  development 
partners) and assessed areas of potential engagement on decentralization reforms. A scoping 
staff study8 has also been commissioned and will be available in October 2009. On the basis of 
these consultations and study, ADB's engagement with decentralization and deconcentration 
will span the medium to long term and will include (i) assisting in implementation of the Organic 
Law, especially the transfer of functions and resources to subnational levels; (ii) supporting 
finalization of a subnational finance law and its implementation; (iii) building the capacity of 
oversight agencies and select provincial and district councils whose members were elected in 
May 2009; (iv) implementing and retrofitting the National Program; and (v) supporting detailed 
articulation  and  implementation  of  functions  in  select  sector  ministries  (e.g.,  the  rural 
development  sectors).  ADB's  comparative  advantage  is  its  strategic  view,  which  will  be 
operationalized and tested through specific interventions, starting with this TA. The TA outputs 
also form priority areas of the draft National Program. 
 
7.  The  decentralization  program  is  fast  becoming  the  Government’s  umbrella  reform 
program,  which  will  have  far-reaching  implications  in  government  systems  and  donor 
interventions.  Despite  the  cautious  approach  of  many  MEF  senior  managers,  virtually  all 
stakeholders welcome the various forms of ADB support. There is a palpable need for advice on 
how to proceed with reforms, and there is a shortage of skills to forge policy and legal drafting 
consensus within MEF. There is a significant scope to design harder forms of infrastructure 
capacity  development  and  general  budget  program  support  for  decentralization  and

deconcentration, which is likely to prove acceptable in relation to MEF borrowing policies. The 
assessments conducted with the Government (both MEF and MOI) strongly underscored the 
importance of sequencing and the need for technical assistance on a priority basis. While this 
TA—which is highly relevant for immediate involvement-- aims to allow time to review reform 
developments, a proposed project preparatory TA in 2010 and a program in 2011 with a mix of 
decentralization,  deconcentration,  and  infrastructure  support  will  help  deliver  an  integrated 
package of governance and public service delivery at the policy and operational levels.  
 
8.  ADB's support to the sector is closely linked to needs, and is coordinated with the 
support provided by other development partners.  Various informal subgroups are linked to a 
development partner decentralization and deconcentration technical working group, including (i) 
a European grouping, which emphasizes democracy and broad governance and very supportive 
of further strengthening the grassroots commune approach; (ii) those associated with the United 
Nations Development Programme, which is project-focused at provincial and district levels but 
still influential on policy and programming direction within MOI and NCDD, where it is seen as 
the  principal  decentralization  adviser  due  to  a  large  project  that  supports  democratic 
development.  This  project  will  be  ending  shortly,  with  the  Department  for  International 
Development  of  the  United  Kingdom  withdrawing  funding  in  late  2009,  and  the  Swedish 
International Development Cooperation Agency poised to do the same in 2010 when current 
funding commitments expire; (iii) those interested mainly in fiscal decentralization, including 
GTZ, United Nations Capital Development Fund (UNCDF), United Nations Children’s Fund, and 
World Bank; and (iv) another project-focused group, including the AusAID, Japan International 
Cooperation Agency, and United States Agency for International Development.  
 
9.  Currently the two main players in fiscal decentralization are UNCDF and World Bank. 
UNCDF's support is important in the policy and legal framework development, although funding 
is limited and there is no financing to support broader implementation as of yet. World Bank is 
considering a proposal to place a fiscal decentralization advisor within MEF and it has been 
agreed that this needs close coordination in relation to similar plans by ADB. Regular meetings 
with  development  partners  over  the  past  year  show  that,  with  continued  consultation  and 
flexibility, there is adequate space in this working group for ADB. The prospects for another 
fruitful ADB and World Bank partnership in Cambodia on the important fiscal decentralization 
area are encouraging, especially in view of close and successful collaboration of the two in this 
sector in the Philippines.   
 
I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact of the TA will be that the regulatory framework for decentralization is in place 
and  operationalized.  A  key  performance  target  is  increased  subnational  government 
expenditures at the provincial and municipal/khan levels. The outcome will be the adoption of a 
regulatory framework for decentralization by policy makers.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The key activities/outputs of the TA are as follows. 
 
(i)  Functional  assignments  linked  to  fiscal  needs/capacities.  Decisions 
regarding functional assignments must be made strategically and in a budgetary 
context. Policy advisory support will be provided to NCDD to draw together an

4  
integrated and coherent functional assignments strategy, incorporating MEF’s 
medium-term  expenditure  framework  and  sector  plans/resource  allocation. 
Recent work on selected ministries’ functions will be a useful starting point in 
developing expenditure assignments. Functional assignment strategies will be 
prepared for the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries; Ministry for Rural 
Development;  and  Ministry  of  Water  Resources  and  Meteorology,  including 
strategies  and  budgets  for  redeployment  of  civil  servants.  Medium-term 
budgetary implications of different scenarios for deconcentrating or decentralizing 
further functions will be examined. More empirical/budget-related work would 
also be used for designing the intergovernmental financing system. As part of 
this component, a review of the National Program to identify any priority areas 
will be done. NCDD will be the Implementing Agency for this component. 
(ii)  Finalizing the legal/regulatory regime for fiscal arrangements. Section 6 of 
the Organic Law is skeletal only and envisages further laws and regulations 
within the context of a subnational Finance Law, which is expected to be passed 
by  the  end  of  2009.  Since  the  draft  law  is  generic  and  provides  a  broad 
framework,  getting  the  lower  level  regulations  is  of  pivotal  importance.  This 
component will finalize and fine-tune such legal reforms in close coordination 
with other development partners, such as World Bank and United Nations Capital 
Development Fund. The Local Finance Department (LFD) of MEF will be the 
Implementing Agency. 
(iii)  Intergovernmental  financing  arrangements.  This  component  will  focus  on 
financial  modeling  of  various  policy  options  for  finalizing  the  system  of 
intergovernmental  financing,  including  unconditional  equalization  grants  and 
conditional grants. It will also examine revenue assignments. Building on the 
current body of work—and given the current thinking of MEF and its tax division 
not to decentralize any significant revenue powers—this component is partly an 
educational/advisory exercise supplemented by modeling of fiscal implications for 
devolving taxation powers. LFD will be the Implementing Agency. 
(iv)  Strengthening  institutional  coordination  arrangements  and  capacity. For 
effective  and  longer-term  management  of  decentralization,  institutional 
arrangements  under  NCDD  will  require  longer-term  capacity  development 
support, in terms of both systems and human resources in selected ministries. 
LFD will also be provided training on local finance and fiscal decentralization 
areas and on establishing links with the NCDD work plan. Therefore, a capacity 
needs  assessment  and  training  in  LFD  and  other  parts  of  MEF  will  occur. 
Capacity needs assessment and training on functional assignments in NCDD; 
MOI;  Ministry  of  Agriculture,  Forestry  and  Fisheries;  Ministry  for  Rural 
Development;  and  Ministry  of  Water  Resources  and  Meteorology  will  be 
prepared, including staff and budget redeployment in the latter three ministries. A 
longer-term  option  of  establishing  a  local  government  academy  for  training 
central  and  subnational  officials  will  be  explored  in  terms  of  organizational 
structure  and  resource  requirements.  NCDD  and  LFD  will  be  implementing 
agencies for this component. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1,000,000 equivalent. The Government has 
requested that ADB finance $800,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB's  TA  funding  program  (Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund-IV).  The  Government  will 
finance  the  remaining  $200,000  equivalent  in  kind  by  providing  office  accommodation,

are plan in Appendix 2.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The Executing Agency will be NCDD in MOI, and the Implementing Agency will be LFD 
in MEF. A small, high-level steering committee with representatives from both ministries will 
guide the implementation of the TA. It will meet regularly to review implementation progress and 
discuss any issues with the ADB project officer.  
 
14.  The  TA  will  be  implemented  over  a  24-month  period  starting  in  November  2009. 
International consultants will be hired for 24 person-months and national consultants for 20 
person-months  to  provide  expertise  in  regional  autonomy,  fiscal  policy  aspects  of 
decentralization, budgeting and planning, intergovernmental fiscal relations, intergovernmental 
financial arrangements, preparation of financial laws and regulations, and capacity building. The 
outline terms of reference and reporting arrangements are in Appendix 3. Four consultants for 
18 international and 20 national person-months, including the team leader, will be hired through 
a  reputable  international  consulting  firm  after  the  biodata  technical  proposal  undergoes  
quality- and cost-based selection (80:20). Two international advisers— the decentralization and 
capacity-building advisers for a total of 6 person-months—will be hired on an individual basis, as 
these  distinct  areas  of  expertise  involved  may  not  be  available  through  a  single  firm.  All 
consultants will be hired by ADB according to its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as 
amended from time to time). 
 
15.  NCDD and LFD will provide adequate furnished office accommodation for the TA team, 
including  telephone  and  fax  lines,  internet  connection  facilities,  and  workshop  secretariat 
support. Basic office and computer equipment will be procured and disposed by the consultants 
in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). The 
disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook.9 
 
II.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Cambodia for Developing an Institutional Framework for Decentralization 
Reforms, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  Consultants will design a policy framework and matrix of reform actions, which will 
advance decentralization in Cambodia consistent with improvements in fiscal, financial, budget 
planning, and management capacities in central agencies and subnational structures. As the 
technical assistance (TA) is focused on supporting the Government's decentralization priorities, 
the  consultants  will  be  providing  inputs  and  must  exercise  flexibly  in  the  design  and 
implementation of policy actions. In addition, they must ensure participation of all stakeholders 
to build consensus and ownership of the reform process. 
 
2.  The  TA  will  require  a  combination  of  international  and  national  experts  who  are 
experienced with international and Cambodian decentralization approaches and who have the 
skills required for regional autonomy, fiscal policy aspects of decentralization, budgeting and 
planning, intergovernmental fiscal relations such as fiscal transfers and various types of grant 
mechanisms,  intergovernmental  financial  arrangements,  preparation  of  financial  laws  and 
regulations, and capacity building. About 24 person-months of international consulting inputs 
and about 20 person-months of intermittent national consulting inputs will be required over 24 
months, the period of TA implementation. Four consultants for 18 international and 20 national 
person-months will be hired through a firm. Two international advisers—the decentralization and 
capacity-building advisers for a total of 6 person-months—will be hired on an individual basis.  
 
3.  The consultants will work in coordination with the team leader and report to the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  project  officer  through  the  team  leader  who  will  ensure  quality, 
integration, and timeliness of outputs. The major reports produced will be inception, midterm, 
draft final, and final at appropriate times containing the required TA outputs in draft or final forms. 
In addition, quarterly reports on status of implementation and any other issues will be produced. 
 
B.  International Consultants (24 person-months) 
 
1.  Regional Autonomy and Fiscal Policy Adviser/Team Leader (international, 10 
person-months) 
 
4.  This  consultant  will  have  appropriate  postgraduate  qualifications  in  economics  and 
public finance and be experienced in managing TA project teams. Experience is required in 
administrative  and  fiscal  aspects of  decentralization,  particularly  in  deconcentrating  service 
delivery functions, designing intergovernmental financing arrangements, and creating policy 
reform frameworks and reform deliverable matrixes. He or she will have a good understanding 
of the overall decentralization reform agenda in Cambodia and will be located at the National 
Committee  for  Democratic  Development  at  Subnational  Level  (NCDD)  Secretariat.  The 
consultant will also be responsible for  
 
(i)  leading, managing, coordinating, and facilitating all aspects of the TA; 
(ii)  providing quality control over all TA activities and outputs;  
(iii)  in  conjunction  with  international  and  national  consultants,  focusing  on  (a) 
developing  an  integrated  and  coherent  government  functional  assignments 
strategy, draft assignment of functional responsibilities in a budgetary context, 
and redeployment of civil servants from specific ministries; (b) capacity building 
on  functional  assignments  for  selected  government  ministries  and  local 
governments;  (c)  providing  limited  support  to  broader  implementation  of  the

National  Program  and  broad  aspects  of  redeployment  of  civil  servants;  (d) 
developing a preliminary design of a future program and investment support; and 
(e) organizing consultative workshops with stakeholders for various outputs. 
 
2.  Fiscal Decentralization and Expenditure Management Adviser (international, 
8 person-months) 
 
5.  This consultant will have appropriate postgraduate qualifications in public finance, law, 
or administration and be experienced in expenditure management at the subnational level. 
Experience is required in designing intergovernmental financing arrangements, including grant 
transfer mechanisms, revenue assignments, and drafting financing rules and regulations. He or 
she will have a good understanding of the decentralization reform agenda in Cambodia and will 
be located in the Local Finance Department (LFD) but may provide general advisory services 
more widely in the Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF).   
 
6.  This  consultant  will  focus  on  (i)  finalizing  the  fiscal/legal  regulatory  framework,  (ii) 
developing  a  framework  for  intergovernmental  financial  arrangements,  and  (iii)  supporting 
capacity building in MEF. The consultant will submit monthly progress reports to the team leader. 
 
3.  Decentralization Adviser (international, 2 person-months, to be appointed as an 
individual) 
 
7.  An internationally recognized authority on decentralization will be engaged as an adviser 
to provide high-level advice to the Government and TA team on the TA outputs, as well as the 
peer review and quality control of the TA’s main outputs. The consultant will  
 
(i)  provide high-level, strategic policy advice to MEF and NCDD on the direction and 
speed of decentralization and deconcentration reforms, 
(ii)   review the major outputs of the TA, 
(iii)  act as a resource person at workshops and seminars supported by the TA, and 
(iv)  facilitate and attend meetings with senior central and subnational government 
officials.   
 
4.  Capacity-Building Adviser (international, 4 person-months, to be appointed as 
an individual)  
 
8.  This  consultant  will  have  appropriate  qualifications  in  public  administration,  human 
resources management, economics, finance, or other closely related decentralization disciplines 
and  have  experience  in  developing  training  modules  in  local  finance  and  functions.  The 
consultant will focus on (i) developing training modules and conducting training on functional 
assignments, (ii) building MEF capacity, (iii) conducting a capacity needs assessment of central 
oversight agencies to address skill gaps, and (iv) exploring the feasibility of establishing a local 
government academy. The consultant will submit monthly progress reports to the team leader 
and will work closely with various ministries. 
 
C.  National Consultants (20 months) 
 
9.  Two national experts will be recruited under this TA. They will work closely with the 
international experts identified above.

Appendix 3  11
1.  Regional  Autonomy  Expert/Project  Administrator  (national,  10  
person-months) 
 
10.  This consultant will have the appropriate qualifications in economics/public finance. He 
or she will help the team leader and, in the latter’s absence, coordinate all aspects of the TA 
with the Government, and between the Government and ADB. He or she will work closely under 
the guidance and supervision of the team leader and will be located at NCDD. The consultant’s 
tasks will include 
 
(i)  providing overall coordination and administrative support to the team leader on 
administrative  and  technical  aspects  of  the  TA,  including  coordination  of 
workshops and seminars, and liaising with government counterparts; 
(ii)  supporting the work of international team leader, particularly in NCDD; 
(iii)  monitoring  developments  in  regional  autonomy,  including  key  legislation  and 
regulations, decrees, and guidelines, and related development partner support, 
and advising the team leader, government counterparts, and ADB of upcoming 
events, milestones, and critical changes affecting the TA in monthly reports; 
(iv)  supporting the international capacity building adviser on functional assignments 
and related areas and 
(v)  compiling all outputs under the TA, and aiding in its closure. 
 
2.  Capacity-Building Expert (national, 10 person-months) 
 
11.  This consultant will have appropriate qualifications in public administration or human 
resources management and be experienced in developing capacity-building initiatives. He or 
she will work with the international team leader and capacity-building adviser and will be located 
at MEF. The consultant’s tasks will include 
 
(i)  participating  in  the  development  of  the  skills  gap  assessment  and  training 
modules by liaising closely with the executing and implementing agencies and 
participating provinces and districts; 
(ii)  supporting the work of the fiscal decentralization adviser at MEF; 
(iii)  supporting the work of the international capacity-building adviser at MEF on fiscal 
decentralization issues; and 
(iv)  participating in workshops and seminars as a resource person.
